title: LCFSTE: Landslide Conditioning Factors and Swin Transformer Ensemble for Landslide Susceptibility Assessment
abstract: Landslide susceptibility assessment (LSA) holds crucial importance in guiding regional disaster prevention and reduction efforts. However, current deep learning (DL) models for LSA encounter challenges like insufficient landslide data samples and uneven distribution. In this article, we develop a new hybrid framework named landslide conditioning factors and swin transformer ensemble (LCFSTE), which integrates landslide conditioning factors (LCFs) and swin transformer (swin-T) for LSA. With this framework, we fully leverage the powerful nonlinear feature extraction capability of swin-T to extract abstract features from both landslides and LCFs. This approach ultimately enhances the precision and reliability of LSA. To assess the performance of our newly proposed framework, we selected Jiuzhaigou County, China, as our study area. First, a dataset for LSA was constructed using historical landslide data and 11 multisource LCFs. Then, these factors were screened through a multicollinearity test and factor importance analysis using variance inflation factor, tolerance, and information gain rate. Subsequently, the dataset was divided into three subsets: 60% for training, 20% for validation, and 20% for testing. Then, the LSA results were compared with four DL models. Seven evaluation metrics (EMs) are chosen to quantitatively evaluate the performance of these five LSA models. The results demonstrated that, among these seven EMs, LCFSTE outperformed the others, achieving the highest score in six out of the seven considered EMs. This outcome highlights the promising applicability of LCFSTE in enhancing LSA accuracy.

LCFSTE: Landslide Conditioning Factors and Swin 
Transformer Ensemble for Landslide Susceptibility 
Assessment 
 
Tao Chen, Senior Member, IEEE Qingye Wang, Zeyang Zhao, Gang Liu, Jie Dou, and Antonio Plaza, Fellow, IEEE 
 
 Abstractâ€”Landslide susceptibility assessment (LSA) holds crucial 
importance in guiding regional disaster prevention and reduction 
efforts. However, current deep learning (DL) models for LSA 
encounter challenges like insufficient landslide data samples and 
uneven di stribution. In this paper, we develop a new  hybrid 
framework named LCFSTE, which integrates landslide 
conditioning factors (LCFs) and Swin Transformer (Swin -T) for 
LSA. Wit h this framework, we fully leverage the powerful 
nonlinear feature extraction capabi lity of Swin -T to extract 
abstract features from both landslides and LCFs. This approach 
ultimately enhances the precision and reliability of LSA. To assess 
the performance of our newly proposed framework, we selected 
Jiuzhaigou County, China, as our study area. Firstly, a dataset for 
LSA was constructed using historical landslide data and 11 multi-
source LCFs. Then, these factors were screened through 
multicollinearity test and factor importance analysis using 
variance inflation factor s, tolerance, and inf ormation gain rate. 
Subsequently, the dataset was divided into three subsets: 60% for 
training, 20% for validation and 20% for testing. Then , the LSA 
results were compared with f our DL models. Seven evaluation 
metrics (EMs) are chosen to quantitative ly evaluate the 
performance of these five LSA models. The results demonstrated 
that, among these seven EMs, LCFSTE outperformed the others, 
achieving the highest score in six out of the seven considered EMs. 
This outcome highlights the promising applicability of LCFSTE in 
enhancing LSA accuracy. 
 
Index Termsâ€”Landslide susceptibility assessment, deep learning, 
Swin Transformer, Jiuzhaigou County. 
 
I. INTRODUCTION 
ANDSLIDE susceptibility is a measure of the likelihood 
of landslides occurring in a specific area based on local 
conditions, indicating the potential impact of slope 
movement on the landscape [1]. It serves as a predictive tool,

(Corresponding author: Tao Chen, Gang Liu.) 
Tao Chen is with the School of Geophysics and Geomatics, China 
University of Geosciences, Wuhan 43 0074, China, also with the Badong 
National Observation and Research Station of Geohazards, China University of 
Geosciences, Wuhan 430074, China, also with the Key Laboratory of National 
Geographic Census and Monitoring, Ministry of Natural Resources, Wuhan  
estimating the areas where landslide s are prone to happen. On 
August 8, 2017, the Jiuzhaigou County  in China experienced a 
devastating earthquake with a magnitude of 7. This seismic 
event triggered a significant number of co -seismic landslides 
and resulted in the emergence of numerous potential landslide 
hazards. Landslide susceptibility assessment (LSA) plays a  
pivotal role as the cornerstone of landslide disaster risk 
assessment. It provides valuable insights to decision -makers 
involved in disaster management and facility construction 
planning [2]. 
The significance of LSA extends to regional disaster 
prevention and mitigation efforts, actively contributing to the 
reduction of future landslide risks in the Jiuzhaigou area. 
Recent advances in LSA research can be divided into three 
areas: statistical methods  (STMs), machine learning (ML) 
models, and deep learning ( DL) models. STMs entail the 
inference of data relationships and offer advantages such as 
simplicity and strong interpretability. The earliest origins of 
LSA research can be traced back to methods like Logistic 
Regression (LR) [3] -[5], Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) 
[6], [7], Information Value (IV) [5], Weight of Evidence 
(WOE) [8], and Frequency Ratio (FR) [9] -[11]. While STMs 
hold several advantages, they also come with some common 
limitations, including cumbersome procedural steps, lower 
computational efficiency, and reduced precision. 
In recent years, many scholars have applied machine learning 
(ML) models to the field of LSA [12], [13]. In comparison to 
STMs, ML techniques prioritize computational efficiency and 
accuracy over interpretability. ML methods commonly 
employed in LSA encompass Artificial Neural Network s 
(ANNs) [14], [15], Support Vector Machines (SVMs) [16], [17] 
and Random Forest s (RFs) [1 8], [19]. Unlike statistical 
approaches, ML algorithms do not necessitate spe cialized

hardware devices like GPUs, resulting in lower computational 
cost. However, before deploying a model into the network, 
feature engineering becomes imperative to reduce feature 
complexity and enhance the prominence of relevant features. 
This task, although crucial, can be challenging and resource -
intensive. 
DL is a subset of ML that employs deep neural networks to 
create more complex models, thereby achieving a deeper 
understanding of the underlying data. While it demands 
powerful hardware resources , DL eliminates the need for 
extensive feature engineering and excels when dealing with 
large datasets. DL can be categorized into five main types: 
CNN-based (Convolutional Neural Networks) [20]-[24], RNN-
based (Recurrent Neural Networks)  [25], [26], DG (D eep 
Generative Models) [27]-[29], GNN (Graph Neural Networks)  
[30], and attention -based mechanisms  [31]-[33]. [34] 
conducted the LSA of Jiuzhaigou County based on the 
transformer model and discovered that its accuracy surpassed 
that of the traditional ML model significantly . [35] proposed a 
feature fusion transformer module built on the basis of the 
transformer framework foundation to fuse all LCFs spatial 
information features.  [36] introduced a spatiotemporal 
transformer (ST-transformer) aimed at enhancing the temporal 
probability prediction of landslides, thereby effectively 
improving the accuracy of landslide hazard assessment. 
With the continuous improvement of computing power, DL 
has achieved great success in the computer vision field and has 
been widely used in LSA  tasks. However, these DL models 
mainly focus on CNN -based and RNN -based models, which 
extract deep information by stacking convolutional layers, 
focusing only on local associations and failing to make effective 
use of global information [3 7], [3 8]. Compared with these 
models, Transformer model does not contain convolution, 
pooling or cyclic operations, which makes it have better 
parallelism and interpretability when processing sequence data. 
At the same time, the self -attention mechanism can capture 
dependencies between different positions in the input sequence, 
which allows the Transformer to better handle global contextual 
information in visual tasks. Swin Transformer (Swin-T) stands 
as an enhancement over traditional Transformer models, which 
has powerful nonlinear and multi -scale feature extraction 
capability when compared to  other DL models.  Swin-T 
employs a local attention window strategy to effectively capture 
local information while processing large -scale images. This 
approach serves to mitigate computational complexity and 
enhance model efficiency.  In addition, Swin -T introduces a 
cross-layer connectivity mechanism, enabling information 
exchange across different lev els within the model architecture. 
This enhances feature reusability and contributes to overall 
performance improvements. 
Based on this , we propose a new framework that integrates 
landslide conditioning factors (LCFs) with the Swin -T. The 
main contributions of our work can be summarized as follows: 
1) we introduce a hybrid framework named LCFSTE, which 
combines LCFs and Swin-T for LSA; 2) the proposed LCFSTE 
is applied to LSA in a landslide-prone area, improving the LSA 
accuracy of the framework. 
The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 
II comprehensively introduces the study areas and overviews 
the datasets employed in  the experiments. Section III outlines 
the experimental steps undertaken to develop the new 
framework. Section IV analyzes the experimental results in 
detail, presenting both qualitative and quantitative findings. 
Finally, Section V concludes the paper with some remarks. 
II. STUDY AREA AND DATA 
A. Study Area 
The study area (Fig. 1) is in a region of Jiuzhaigou County, 
situated in the northern Aba Tibetan and Qiang Autonomous 
Prefecture, Sichuan province, China. The area lies within the 
latitude of 33Â°5â€²59â€³-33Â°14â€²58â€³N and longitude of 103Â°42â€²13â€³ -
103Â°51â€²53â€³E, covering an area of 250 km2. The region features 
a river system, with the Bai he river running across the entire 
county and flowing into the Baishuihe river. It is a typical deep-
incised valley lo cated in the transition zone between the 
Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, Western Sichuan Plateau, mountains, 
and Sichuan Basin. Its elevation varies from 2641 m to 4455 m, 
with a peak difference of 1814 m. As a result, this location 
presents various morphological p rocesses and landforms, 
making it prone to the development of geo -hydrological 
hazards. 
B. Landslide inventory map 
In this study, the landslide inventory map was obtained 
through the visual interpretation from pre - and post -event 
Google Earth image s (Fig. 1). A total of 2171 landslides were 
identified, covering a combined area of 8.392 Km2. The largest 
landslide in terms of area was 0.5265 square kilometers, while 
the smallest measured 13.9581 square meters.  Most of the 
landslides in the study area are relatively small and are 
concentrated in the vicinity of the epicenter, fault zones, and 
valley slopes.

Fig. 1. Location of the study area. 
C. Landslide conditioning factors 
Due to the complexity of landslide development mechanisms 
and the differences between landslide types, there are no 
guidelines for selecting LCFs. In this study, based on previous 
studies and expert knowledge, 11 L CFs were selected: 
elevation, slope,  terrain relief  (TER), aspect, plan curvature  
(PLC), profile curvature  (PRC), distance to faults (DTF), 
lithology, distance to rivers (DTR) , modified normalized 
difference water index (MNDWI),  and normalized difference 
vegetation index (NDVI) . The first six factors were extracted 
from the digital elevation model (DEM)  with a spatial 
resolution of 30 m, which was downloaded from geospatial data 
cloud (http://www.gscloud.cn/search). The fault and lithology 
data were obtained by vectorization, based on the 1:200 ,000 
scale geological map database of the National Geological 
Archive (http://www.ngac.org.cn/Map/List). The river vector 
illustration was modified based on the 1:250,000 scale national 
basic geographic database, combined with pre -earthquake 
remote sensing image data. Additionally, Landsat 8 OLI Image 
was used to obtain MNDWI and NDVI data. Table I shows the 
detailed information of the LCFs.

III. METHODOLOGY 
The proposed LCFSTE framework encompasses three main 
parts (Fig. 2). The first part is data processing, which includes data 
preprocessing, LCFs selection, and dataset creation for the 
LCFSTE. The second part of the framework ensembles the LCFs 
and Swin-T algorithms. Finally, model evaluation is conducted in 
the third part of the framework. Seven evaluation metrics (EMs) 
are employed to compare the performance of our proposed 
LCFSTE framework to that of other four DL methods.

Fig. 2. Flowchart of LCFSTE. 
A. Data preprocessing 
In our framework, data preprocessing involves two essential 
steps: resampling and image standardization. To ensure 
uniform row and column numbers, resampling is conducted 
using the bilinear interpolation method, accounting for 
variations in data resolution [ 39]. Following resampling, all 
input data undergo standardization using the Z -score method, 
thereby achieving a consistent data distribution with a mean of 
0 a nd a variance of 1. This standardization harmonizes data 
distributions across different dimensions and accelerates model 
convergence [40].  
B. LCFs selection 
The process of selecting factors plays a pivotal role in 
determining the overall performance of the model. On one 
hand, a substantial presence of noise, characterized by factors 
with negligible or zero contribution rates in the dataset, can 
significantly distort the model's predictive outcomes, impeding 
the accurate assimilation of gen uine landslide characteristics. 
On the other hand, robust interconnections among the factors 
may introduce data redundancy, ultimately diminishing the 
model's efficiency and exerting an influence on the allocation 
of feature weights throughout the learning  process [ 41]. 
Consequently, in this study we performed collinearity testing 
and importance analysis on the LCFs prior to the construction 
of the landslide sample datasets. 
1) Multi-collinearity Test: Multi-collinearity is used to test 
whether there is non -perfect collinearity between LCFs. It can 
be judged by VIF  (Variance Inflation Factor)  or Tol 
(Tolerance). VIF is calculated as shown in Eq. (1). Tol is the 
reciprocal of the VIF. 
VIF =

where ð‘¦ð‘– refers to the actual value, ð‘¦Ì‚ð‘– is the predicted value, and 
ð‘¦ refers to the average value. 
In general, the calculation result of ð‘…ð‘–
2 is between 0 and 1. 
The closer ð‘…ð‘–
2 is to 1, the greater th e number of independent 
variables that can be obtained through linear regression of other 
independent variables. Generally, a factor should be removed 
when its VIF exceeds 10 or 5.  
2) Importance Analysis: To assess the influence of each LCF 
on the performance of model, a comprehensive importance 
analysis of the 11 LCFs was conducted prior to model 
construction. In this study, we employed the information gain 
ratio (IGR) to determine the contribution of these LCFs  to a 
landslide event [42]. The higher the value of a specific element, 
the more significant the corresponding LCF's contribution to 
the LSA model. 
C. Dataset construction 
After extracting LCFs through data preprocessing and LCF 
analysis, it is essential to create a dataset before feeding it into 
the model. Given the spatial correlations of landslides at the 
pixel level, this study constructs the dataset using three -
dimensional sample blocks. To begin, the LCFs are assembled 
into a three-dimensional matrix (H, W, C), with H representing 
height, W representing width, and C indicating the number of 
channels (which corresponds to the number of LCFs ). The 
subsequent steps involve patch generation  and augmentation :

firstly, it is assessed whether the majority of pixel labels within 
a sample block align with the central pixel label. If they match, 
the sample is retained; if there is a mismatch, it is considered an 
invalid sample. Following this evaluation, all landslide samples 
are selected, along with an eq ual number of non -landslide 
samples. Subsequently, seven methods are employed for data 
augmentation, including 90Â° , 180Â° , and 270Â°  rotations, left-
right mirroring, and mirroring followed by 90Â° , 180Â° , and 270Â°  
rotations, effectively expanding the sample li brary to eight 
times its original size . Finally, the sample set is divided into 
training, validation, and test sets in a 6:2:2 ratio. 
D. LeNet 
LeNet is a relatively straightforward CNN, initially designed 
for recognizing handwritten text [ 43]. The classic LeNet -5 
architecture comprises two two -dimensional convolutional 
layers for extracting features, each followed by a down -
sampling layer, as well as a pooling layer for reducing feature 
dimensionality (Fig. 3). Ultimately, it incorporates a classifi er 
consisting of two fully connected layers and a Gaussian 
connected layer to produce classification results. 
 
Fig. 3. Network structure of LeNet. 
E. VGG 
The VGG network employs a series of small consecutive 
convolutional kernels (3x3) and maximum pool layer s (2x2) to 
build a deep neural network [ 44]. This architectural design 
allows for a total depth of either 16 layers or 19 layers . In our 
work, we employed the VGG16 model to map the landslide 
susceptibility, since it is one of the most widely used VGG 
networks. VGG16 consists of 16 hidden layers , including 13 
convolutional layers (Conv-3) and pooling layers, followed by 
3 fully connected layers  (FC). The Network structure of VGG 
is shown in Fig. 4. 
 
Fig. 4. Network structure of VGG. 
F. ResNet 
ResNet effectively addresses the challenges of gradient 
vanishing and exploding in the training of deep neural networks 
by introducing skip connections within the network architecture, 
resulting in significant enhancements in model performance  
[23]. At the heart of ResNet lies the Residual Block, comprised 
of two convolutional layers. Notably, the output of the second 
convolutional layer is combined with the input, creating a 
crucial junction that enables the residual block to glean and 
learn residual information . Finally, there is a global average 
pooling layer and a fully connected layer for classification. 
The specific network employed in this study is ResNet50, 
distinguished by its inclusion of 50 convolutional and fully 
connected layers. This substantial depth empowers the network 
to capture and comprehend progressively intricate and abstract 
features. The ResNet network architecture is shown in Fig. 5. 
 
Fig. 5. Network structure of ResNet. 
G. DenseNet 
DenseNet's defining feature lies in the interconnections 
between every layer of dense layers. These dense connections 
within the Dense Block not only mitigate the vanishing gradient 
problem but also bolster feature propagation [45]. Furthermore, 
DenseNet incorporates a structure known as the Dense Block -
Transition to maintain consistent feature map sizes at each layer. 
Transition encompasses transition layers, comprised of a 1x1 
convolution layer and a max -pooling layer. In pursuit of 
enhanced computational efficienc y, the DenseNet -BC variant 
was conceived, with 'B' signifying 'Bottleneck.' This variant 
comprises only two convolution layers, each with a preceding 
1x1 convolution step to replace the conventional dense layer. 
The DenseNet architecture employed in this study is elucidated 
in Fig.6, where the quantity of Dense Blocks in Stages 1 
through 4 is specified as (6, 12, 24, 16). 
 
Fig. 6. Network structure of DenseNet.

H. LCFSTE 
By integrating LCFs and Swin -T, the LCFSTE model not 
only enhances the accuracy of landslide susceptibility 
assessments but also significantly improves computational 
efficiency. The second part of Fig.2 illustrates the specific 
structure of LCFSTE. In the context of LCFSTE,  the Swin-T 
network structure plays a pivotal role in feature extraction. The 
key breakthrough of Swin -T lies in its innovative hierarchical 
grouping attention mechanism, which empowers LCFSTE to 
efficiently handle large -scale, high -resolution images and 
capture global landslide features while demanding fewer 
computational resources. 
When dealing with a patch block composed of LCFs, 
LCFSTE initiates the process by dividing the patch block into 
non-overlapping image blocks through Patch Par tition. 
Subsequently, LCFSTE is organized into four stages, with each 
stage comprising Patch Merging and multiple Swin -T blocks. 
The specific architecture of these blocks is visually depicted in 
Fig. 7 . It includes essential components like Layer Norm, 
Multi-Layer Perceptron ( MLP), Window Multi -head Self 
Attention (W -MSA), and Shifted Window Multi -Head Self 
Attention (SW -MSA). Both W -MSA and SW -MSA compute 
the MSA within the window. SW -MSA, on the other hand, 
ensures connectivity among non -overlapping windows and re-
calculates self-attention within the window of the shifted 
feature map. These two Swin -T modules are interconverted to 
facilitate information exchange between neighboring blocks. 
   
Fig. 7. Network Structure of two connected Swin-T blocks. 
I. Experimental environment and hyperparameter 
optimization 
Table II presents the computer hardware employed in the 
experiments conducted in this study. The software was 
developed within the Python 3.6.2 environment and built on the 
PyCharm 2021 and Microsoft Visual Studio 2015  software 
platform. The experiments were executed on the Linux-Ubuntu 
18.04.05 LTS operating system. Furthermore, PyTorch was 
installed as the primary artificial intelligence develo pment 
framework, with Keras and TensorFlow serving as 
supplementary tools. 
TABLE II 
COMPUTER HARDWARE INFORMATION 
Item Parameter 
CPU Intel Xeon(R) Silver 4210R CPU@2.4GHZÃ— 40 
GPU GeForce RTX 3090/PCle/SSE2 
Memory 128GB 
Hard disk 8TB 
Optimizing hyperparameters represents a pivotal phase in 
model debugging, as the right combination can yield maximum 
model performance. In this research, we employed the cross -
entropy function as loss function . Stochastic Gradient Descent 
algorithm was chosen as the optimizer as it not only converges 
rapidly, but also displayed strong performance across various 
accuracy metrics. The initial learning rate set to 0.00007 and the 
batch size set to 32 for each learning iteration. The network was 
trained for 100 epochs, and the loss value on the validation set 
was monitored during training. 
J. Model evaluation metrics 
In this study, seven EMs were selected to access the 
performance of the LSA model, which were overall accuracy 
(OA), Precision (Pr), Recall  (Re), F1 score (F1), Matthews 
correlation coefficient (MCC), Kappa coefficient (Kappa), and 
AUC. These seven EMs are defined as follows: 
1) OA. It measures the proportion of correct predictions made 
by a model over the total predictions.  The calculation of OA is 
shown in Eq. (3).  
ð‘‚ð´ =

where TP (Ture Positive) represents correctly predicted 
landslide samples, and TN (True Negative) stands for correctly 
predicted non-landslide samples. A False Positive (FP) occurs 
when the actual value is a non -landslide, but the model 
incorrectly predicts the sample as a landslide. A False Negative 
(FN) arises when the actual value is a landslide, but the model 
incorrectly predicts the sample as a non-landslide. 
2) Pr. Precision is the ratio of correctly predicted landslide 
observations to the total predi cted landslide sample. Precision 
is calculated by Eq. (4).

prediction, and -1 indicates total disagreement between

6) Kappa. Kappa coefficient measures the agreement 
between observed and expected clas sifications while 
considering the possibility of the agreement occurring by 
chance. The equation of Kappa is shown as follows.

7) AUC . Area under curve measures the entire two -
dimensional area underneath the entire ROC (Receiver 
Operating Characteristic) curve. It is used to evaluate the 
performance of binary classification models and represents the 
model's ability to distinguish between positive and negative 
classes. AUCs close to 1 indicate high accuracy, while closer to 
0.5 indicate low accuracy. 
IV. RESULTS AND ANALYSIS 
A. Analysis of LCFs 
1) Multi -collinearity test of LCFs.  The factor collinearity 
indexes of the study were calculated. The results in Table III 
show the Tol and VIF values of the study area. It can be seen 
that the VIF values of all LCFs are less than 5, which indicates 
that there is no need to remove any LCF.

2) Importance analysis of LCFs : The illustration in Fig. 8  
displays the distribution of importance rankings for each LCF 
in the study area. Observably, the lithology factor holds the 
highest IGR value (0.0130), indicating its paramount 
contribution to the model. Next in rank are the MNDWI and 
NDVI factors, both at 0.0115, followed by the planar curvature 
and profile curvature  factors. The elevation and terrain relief 
factors exhibit the lowest IGR values (both at 0.0015), 
indicating their comparatively minimal contribution to the 
modeling process. 
 
Fig. 8. Importance ranking distribution of each LCFs. 
B. Comparison of LSA results 
The landslide susceptibility maps are obtained by using the 
five LSA models. Then the natural breakpoint method [45]-[47] 
was used to divide the susceptibility category into five levels: 
very high (VH), high (HI), moderate (MO), low (LO), and very 
low (VL) ( Fig. 9 ). Based on the classification results of the 
natural breakpoint method, the classification thresholds for 
landslide susceptibility values obtained by LCFSTE are 0.10, 
0.31, 0.56, and 0.81, respectively. 
The area of VH zone is concentrated in and around the 
landslide sites, with HI and MO susceptibility category 
radiating outward. The LO and VL susceptibility areas covering 
the largest extent, with some scattered small landslides.  
However, it can be seen that the grain size of the susceptible 
regions in ResNet is significantly coarser compared to the other 
four LSA models. This suggests that the transition of the region 
is not smooth. The VH areas of large landslides are connected 
together, with the finest grain size observed in LCFSTE. 
Additionally, the LSA results of LeNet seems not reasonable, 
as the central areas of some large landsli des are categorized as 
MO even LO susceptible areas rather than VH areas.  
Additionally, the LSA results of LeNet seems not reasonable, 
as the central areas of some large landslides are categorized as 
HI susceptible areas rather than VI areas. Therefore, vi sually, 
LCFSTE is the most reliable among the five LSA models. 
Specifically with regard to the distribution of LSA results 
from the LCFSTE model, from a lithologic perspective, it can 
be found that HI and VH zones are mostly distributed within 
Carboniferous System, which is consistent with the fact that 
Carboniferous System are usually susceptible to erosion.  In 
terms of topography, HI and VH zones are mostly located in 
areas of undulating terrain and high slopes.  This illustrates the 
importance of topographic elements for LSA.

C. Model performance evaluation 
Assessing the metrics of OA, Precision, Recall, F1, MCC, 
and Kappa (Table IV), the LCFSTE model showcases 
superior values across most indicators. Notably, the ResNet 
model exhibits the highest Recall value. The OA of the 
LCFSTE model stands at approximatel y 87.39%, with 
DenseNet following at 86.26%, ResNet at 85.51%, and the 
LeNet and VGG models ranking the lowest at 84.29%.

In terms of Recall, the ResNet  model attains the highest 
value at 0.9311, followed by LeNet at 0.9232, DenseNet at 
0.9162, LCFSTE at 0.9119, and the least favorable value of 
0.8883 from the VGG model. Additionally, other indicators 
such as Precision, Kappa, F1, and MCC follow a similar  
trend as OA across the models, affirming that the LCFSTE 
model demonstrates superior predictive capabilities. Hence, 
it stands out as the most promising model for LSA task. 
The ROC curves displaying the performance of five LSA 
models using the testing dataset are presented in Fig. 10. The 
LCTSTE model leads with the highest AUC value of 0.9444, 
followed by DenseNet at 0.9382, ResNet at 0.9292, LeNet 
at 0.9238, and the lowest AUC is attributed to VGG, 
registering 0.8681. 
Based on the above findings, it is clear that the  LCFSTE 
model achieves the overall best performance  among these 
five LSA models, since it resulted in the  six highest 
accuracies out of the seven EMs.

V. DISCUSSIONS 
In this study, the performance of the LCFSTE framework 
represent a remarkable advance than the other comparable 
models and models proposed by other scholars. For example, 
Kikuchi et al reported an AUC value of 0.911 for thei r CNN 
model [48], while our LCFSTE model achieved an AUC value 
of 0.94, which shows that the optimization of model mechanism 
can improve the prediction accuracy. Chen et al explore the 
potential applications of CNN hybrid ensemble metaheuristic 
optimization algorithms, namely beluga whale optimization 
and coati optimization algorithm, for landslide susceptibility 
mapping [49]. The AUC values of the two optimized models 
are 0.906 and 0.919 respectively, which are lower than the 
LCFSTE model that has not been optimized in this paper, 
reflecting the excellent performance of the LCFSTE model. 
While the LCFSTE framework we introduced demonstrated 
robust performance in LSA, it faces significant challenges 
within this domain. Firstly, the selection of LCFs may introduce 
uncertainties in the LSA due to variations in the importance of 
each LCF among the five methods (Fig. 9). Lithology emerges 
with the highest importance index, followed by NDVI, 
MNDWI, PLC, PRC, aspect, DTF, slope, and DTR. El evation 
and TER, on the other hand, register the lowest importance 
indices. This implies that in the study area, lithology 
significantly influences LSA, as different rock types have 
varying impacts on landslide occurrences. Despite efforts to 
calculate the  importance of each LCF, discrepancies persist, 
introducing errors and diminishing LSA accuracy [50]-[52]. 
Secondly, our work did not classify different types of landslides 
when applying the five LSA methods, potentially introducing 
uncertainty. Prior stud ies have shown that landslide 
susceptibility can be more accurately assessed by considering 
individual types based on their distinct spatial incidences [4], 
[53]. Thirdly, the absence of complete and coherent landslide 
inventory data in the area introduces further uncertainties. This 
deficiency may lead to unidentified new landslides in the study 
area, which might not be accounted for in existing landslide 
inventory datasets. 
VI. CONCLUSIONS 
In this paper, we proposed a new LCFSTE hybrid framework, 
which ensemble s LCFs and Swin -T for LSA.  We selected 
Jiuzhaigou County as our study area and constructed a dataset 
that included  historical landslide data and eleven LCFs. We 
then conducted multicollinearity test and importance analysis to 
screen the LCFs . Subsequently, the dataset was divided into 
three subsets for training, validation, and testing. To 
quantitatively assess the performance of the LCFSTE 
framework, we employed seven EMs and compared its results 
with four other DL models . The LSA results show that the 
spatial distribution of historical landslides and the VH and H 
zones obtained from the LCFSTE framework are in general 
agreement. Statistically, the LCFSTE framework outperforms 
the other four models in six out of the seven E Ms. These 
findings underscore  the LCFSTE framework's exceptional 
ability to extract abstract features from both landslides and 
LCFs. In summary, our study demonstrates the effectiveness of 
the LCFSTE framework in improving the accuracy of LSA.

Tao Chen  (Senior Member, IEEE) received the 
Ph.D. degree in photogrammetry and remote 
sensing from Wuhan University, Wuhan China, in 
2008.  
He is currently an Associate Professor with the 
School of Geophysics and Geomatics, China 
University of Geosciences, Wuhan, China. He has 
authored or coauthored more than 60 scientific 
papers including IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON 
GEOSCIENCE AND REMOTE SENSING, IEEE 
JOURNAL OF SELECTED TOPICS IN APPLIED 
EARTH OBSERVATIONS AND REMOTE 
SENSING, International Journal of Applied Earth Obser vation and 
Geoinformation, et al, and guest edited 10 journal special issues. From 2015 to 
2016, he was a Visiting Scholar in University of New South Wales, Sydney, 
Australia. His research interests include image processing,  machine learning, 
and geological remote sensing. 
Dr. Chen serves as the associate editor for the IEEE JOURNAL OF 
SELECTED TOPICS IN APPLIED EARTH OBSERVATIONS AND 
REMOTE SENSING. 
 
 Qingye Wang  received the B.S. degree in 
geoinformation science and technology and M.S. 
degree in Resources and Environment from China 
University of Geosciences, Wuhan, in 2019 and 
2023, respectively. 
Her current main research interests are landslide 
susceptibility mapping and deep learning. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Zeyang Zhao  received the B.S. degree from 
Chengdu University of Technology in 2021, 
majoring in Geographic Information Science, is 
now pursuing the M.S. degree at China University 
of Geosciences, Wuhan, China.  
His current main research interests include 
landslide susceptibility mapping and deep learning. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Gang Liu  received the Ph.D. degree in 
Cartography and Geographic Information 
Engineering from Southwest Jiaotong University, 
Chengdu, China, in 2014. 
He is currently a Professor with the College of 
Earth Sciences, Chengdu University of Technology, 
Chengdu, China. He has authored or coauthored 
more than 50 papers including International Journal 
of Geographical Information Science, Transactions 
in GIS, Computers Environment and Urban 
Systems, Sustainable Cities and Society, Journal of 
the Geological Society. From 2018-2019, he was a 
Visiting Scholar in The University of Georgia, 
Athens, GA, USA. His research interests include spatial network, spatial 
analysis, geo-data modeling, image interpretation, etc. 
 
Jie Dou is a Full Professor at the China University 
of Geosciences, China. He obtained his Ph.D. from 
the University of Tokyo and extended his 
experience at the University of Tokyo, the Public 
Works Research Institute, etc. He has participated 
in research p rojects on earthquake/rainfall -
triggered geohazards, spatial analysis with artificial 
intelligence (AI), and risk mitigation. He got a 
Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) 
fellowship. He has authored/ co-authored over 100 
peer-reviewed articles. He served as an Associate 
Editor of Frontiers in Earth Science, and on the editorial boards of several other 
international journals, like the Journal of Mountains Science, Geocarto 
International, Geomatics, Natural Hazards and Risk. He has besides serve d as 
a reviewer for over 30 ISI-listed international journals. He has been a steering 
committee member for several commissions/working groups of international 
academic societies, such as the World Landslide Forum 5, BIGS2021, 
BIGS2023, etc. 
 
Antonio Plaza (Fellow, IEEE) received the M.Sc. 
and Ph.D. degrees in computer engineering from the 
Department of Technology of Computers and 
Communications, University of Extremadura, 
Badajoz, Spain, in 1999 and 2002, respectively.  
He is currently a Full Professor and the Head of 
the Hyperspectral Computing Laboratory, 
Department of Technology of Computers and 
Communications, University of Extremadura. He 
has authored more than 600 publications and guest 
edited 10 journal special issues. He has reviewed more than 500 m anuscripts 
for over 50 different journals.  
Dr. Plaza served as the Editor -in-Chief for the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON 
GEOSCIENCE AND REMOTE SENSING from 2013 to 2017. He is included 
the Highly Cited Researchers List (Clarivate Analytics) from 2018 to 2020.
